_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Name: Ottawa Lake Co-op Elevator

Location:7433 Lynch Rd, Ottawa Lake, MI

Contact: Scott Wahl or Tim Hill

 

RMP Executive Summary below:

 

1. Facility Policy: The owners, management and employees of Ottawa Lake Coop Elevator are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Ottawa Lake Volunteer Fire Department, Monroe County LEPC, and/or others authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the public and the environment.



2. Facility Information. The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of products to farmers. The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production, Anhydrous ammonia is stored in tanks designed for this purpose.



3. The worst-case release scenario is not listed in the executive summary for security reasons. The alternate case release scenario is not listed in the executive summary for security reasons.



4. Accidental Release Prevention Program. This facility complies with state rules relating to the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. These regulations administered by the Department of Agriculture are consistent with CGA G-2.1 (formerly ANSI K61.1) and OSHA 29 CFR 1910.111 regarding the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.



5. Five-Year Accident History. There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia during the past five-years that have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, has there been any accidental releases resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage, or environmental damage.



6. Emergency Response Program. The facility has implemented an Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38 and provides state and local authorities the emergency planning and community ri

ght-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA). Employees do not respond to a major release. If a significant release of anhydrous ammonia takes occurs, appropriate response is to evacuate the area and call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our Emergency Action Plan.



7. Planned Changes to improve Safety. Safety improvements are an on-going process at this facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe practices and operations. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
